lines.text:
[to Marlowe]
As usual, I'm just presenting the grim facts. Colonel Secord doesn't seem to understand that the coffee tastes better when the latrines are dug downstream instead of upstream. How do you like *your* coffee, Colonel?
They're just kids from a military school.
Yeah, but they keep comin'.
I don't understand a man like Miles giving up that easily.
Maybe losing that arm took some of the fight out of him.
No... the man I knew could lose both arms and still try to kick you to death.
They'll catch up to you and cut you to pieces, you nameless, fatherless scum. I just wish I could be there to see it.
If it happens, Miss Hunter, you will be.
[after Marlowe gets slapped]
I suggest you see a doctor.
Hey there - we're Confederates, but we ain't hostile - honest.
How are Susan amd the kids?
Oh, they're fine. They're in Vicksburg. I suspect you'll be seeing them soon.

[pats Miles'leg]
Nice try, Jonathan.
Look here, colonel, I didn't ask to be assigned to this mission...
Kirby, you tangle with me, I'll have your hide.
You're welcome to that too sir, if it's in the line of duty.
Now come off it Colonel, even you were born.
You're not going to burn the town down Major?
No ma'am just war supplies; cotton, railroad equipment, contraband ma'am.
Contraband? That's me, ain't it?
How many men does it take to look after one lone female?
We was respectful, real respectful, Colonel.
You told us it was all right as long as we could see the top of her head.
You said that?
Well, uh...
Then there's one more thing...
[slaps Marlow hard]

[military cadets have opened fire]
What are you going to do now *Mister* Col. Marlowe?
With all due respect, m'am, I'm gonna get the hell outta here.
Major Gray, an actor... and Colonel Secord almost a senator... but Colonel Marlowe, you must be a professional soldier.
No, prior to this current insanity I was a railroad engineer.

[bending over with a plate of chicken, revealing ample cleavage]
Do you prefer the leg... or the breast?
I've had quite enough of both, thank you.

[pushing Hannah and Lukey into the room]
Why don't you ask them what they think your chances are of blowing up Newton Station and heading to Baton Rouge?
Where did you pick up that Reb colonel?
In the telegraph office, sir.
The telegraph office?
[officers begin to scramble]
Alright, Secord, you know what to do.

[during firefight]
I didn't want this. I tried to avoid a fight!
That's why I took up medicine.

[after knocking out the deserters and giving Goodbody a pistol. Bows low]
Compliments of Miss Hannah Hunter of Greenbriar.

[entering the hospital]
Kendall, what's Mitchell's name doing on the sick list?
Please wait your turn - the doctor will be with you shortly.

[indicating Hopkins]
What's this?
Hopkins, my assistant.
Is he going along?
He's a good man, I need him.

[grabbing Sgt. Mitchell by the arm]
Come on, Mitch, I've got some whiskey in my locker...

[forces Sgt. Mitchell back on the bed]
He's staying here and those are my orders!
You've read the whole book, haven't you?
Have you thought about how you're going to get back?
Have you, sir?
Well, I guess I asked for that. I just hate to think of you spending the rest of the war in Andersonville; it's a hell-hole.
That's a pretty primitive outlook; medically speaking, that is.
Well, doctor, war isn't exactly a civilized business.

[preparing to fight]
What are the rules gonna be, Colonel?
Make up your own.

[hits Marlow in the jaw as he is taking off his blouse]
You said no rules.
Roses are red, violets are blue, the camera is looking right at you... oh, I simply must have another; that man in the white coat moved.
That's not all he's gonna be moving.
The Major seems to be out of uniform. Where are your sidearms, Kendall?
If you check the book, Colonel, you'll see that a Regimental Surgeon doesn't wear one.

[Angrily, to Gen Hurlburt]
First you cut out our artillery, then the wagons, and now you want to saddle us with a medical unit!

[immediately after Dunker's death]
If, if, maybe, perhaps... what's the matter, Medicine Man...

[throws whiskey in Marlowe's face]
Alright, section hand, I've had you! Strip your blouse.

[Wipes his face]
I think you're right.
[Calls out]
Orderly! Horses!

[offers his hand to Kendall]
I don't blame you if you... slap it away. Shake hands?
[they shake]
So long, Croaker.
Take care, Section Hand. And if you should run into another doctor...
Yeah, I know... tree moss.
You're not going to burn the town down Major?
No ma'am just war supplies; cotton, railroad equipment, contraband ma'am.
Contraband? That's me, ain't it?
How old are you?
Thirty-two, sir.
Stand with that group over there.
Hey, lookee here, the sun, it comes up in th' east every time, don't it?
It do in Missouri.
Well, then if that's th' east, we ain't headed north, we're goin' south.
Smack dab inta reb country!
